name: Ruta Vertigo Via Ferrata
description:
Introduction

UPDATE 2023: As of Nov 2023, not sure when or if this will ever open again. According to local guides, the company who built the Via Ferrata (with public funding) was upset that other guiding companies were not paying them so they took the zipline and bridge down with no future plans to put them back up.

The via ferrata was installed in 2007 by Geo Aventura in Monterrey. Contact them directly for the final word on status of the route.

This is an amazing Via Ferrata, one of the longest that exist in Mexico.

Approach

Park in the community just off the paved road. In recent years there has usually been a police car parked here -- tell the officers (in Spanish) that you are there to climb the via ferrata, and ask if it is okay to leave your car(s). From the parking area hike through the little village up the dirt road to a small abandoned overlook building. From there a trail leads up to the base of the wall, at a low saddle in the rocky fin above you.

.*** As of June 2019 The bottom 25 feet of the ferrata has been intentionally removed *** A locked ladder is used by the commercial guides to access the ferrata. If you go on your own you will have to climb to make up for the missing ladder. The climbing grade is around 5.9. Three bolts on the route are available for clipping. Either sport climb up this, or alternatively if your group cannot meet that skill level while lead-climbing, suggest bringing a long climbing stick-clip to clip bolts above you as you ascend, and doing a running top rope. Once the first person is up, everyone else will have to ascend the rope up to the first rungs, so bring ascenders or top-belay the rest of the group. Having rock climbing shoes for the first person is a good idea.

Descent

You will ascend by climbing rocks and metal rungs all the way to the top of a 1800ft rock fin. You will negotiate dropoffs, spooky traverses, a tibetan bridge, and a crazy 60ft aluminum ladder suspended over hundreds of feet of air.

Zipline Deproach: Once at the top, if you brought a metal zipline trolley (such as the Petzl Tandem) for each person and know how to use them you may run the multiple 3000ft ziplines that zigzag down from the peak you just climbed. Be sure to use trolleys with steel and not aluminum rollers -- we had a brand new aluminum roller trolley disintegrate on the steel cable. You can also rent these from the rock climbing store in Monterrey for around 400 pesos (check before your trip to see how many they have available, and they likely will only speak Spanish with you).

There are three ziplines. Ensure you also have a brake lanyard (sling + carabiner) or equivalent. You will likely not need to brake on the 1st zipline, but you will almost certainly need to do so on the 3rd (see detailed notes on braking below).

After the first zipline, there is a little more via ferrata and then a trail. From the bottom of the trail you will rappel down to the station for the second zipline -- this rappel is 130'.

.***PLEASE NOTE*** The second zipline cable is meant to be used by lowering each person on rope. It is TOO STEEP to be ziplined freely. NOTE: 220ft of rope IS NOT ENOUGH. You will need around 250ft or more (exact length unknown). Either skip this zipline altogether and have everyone rappel from the station, or you can lower with two shorter ropes tied together. Regardless, the final person will need to rappel; the drop is 145' from the station. A fatality occurred on this zipline by someone trying to descend it with too short of a rope, and he ziplined the remaining distance. He crashed at high speed into the bottom and died.

You can do the 3rd zipline but be warned (yet again) about the need for serious braking. If you do this zipline, you will end up on a final bit of via ferrata rungs that end approximately 115' above the ground, and you will need to rappel from here as well. Alternatively, you can skip the 3rd zipline altogether and just walk from the bottom of the 2nd zipline down the hillside to your car.

BRAKING: Note that using a steel carabiner on the steel cable does not really provide any friction; you will want an aluminum carabiner that will be heavily worn due to the braking and need to be disposed of afterward. Alternatively, some locals wear a thick leather work glove and reach up to grab the cable and slow themselves, but this is quite scary to do in practice when you are whizzing along and you risk *extreme* injury to your hand. Another option is to use a leather belt looped around the cable and attached to your harness with a spare via ferrata lanyard biner; pull down on this to slow. Be sure that the belt is made of genuine leather -- fake leather belts will instantly rip in two and not provide any braking. The first person is in greatest need of braking -- for the rest you should leave someone on the platform to catch anyone with excess speed, and/or push a backpack on a trolley out on the cable that they can crash into and slow themselves. Depending on wind conditions, you may not need any braking, or be in dire need of it.

Rappel Deproach: If you don't have zipline trolleys, the back of the mountain is a vertical wall that can be rappelled in multiple stages. It's scary, but it will get you back to safe ground. Do not use the most decrepit rappel stations, i.e. the ones with railroad nails instead of pitons and barbwire loops instead of rappel rings. But depending on how you break up the rappels you might not have much of a choice.

Make sure you tie a big knot at the end of the rope before going down, and that as soon as you find the next station you tie the end of the rope to a bolt to avoid others to rappel off the end of the rope by mistake.

Via ferrata Deproach: A final option would be to just climb back down the via ferrata.

Useful Video: https://youtu.be/GBVFDUwUbqA

Exit

Once safely back on firm ground hike back to your vehicle.

Red tape

This via ferrata was built by a commercial company using public money on public land and therefore accessible for use by the public. If you are not experienced enough to run the ferrata on your own you can hire a local company to guide you. Many adventure companies in Monterrey can lead you. Here are a couple examples:

  • http://aventurs.com.mx/
  • http://www.ecoprojects.com.mx/LaRutaVertigo

Beta sites

  • Rockclimbing.com
